intro: Annona cacans var. glabriuscula, commonly known as the rough custard apple, is a tropical plant native to Central and South America. It is a small evergreen tree or shrub that typically grows to a height of 3–5 meters. The plant produces large, fragrant flowers that are usually greenish-yellow in color. Its fruit is a rough, spiky berry that turns yellow when ripe, containing a juicy, sweet pulp. The leaves are simple, alternate, and have a rough, hairy texture, which contributes to its common name.
